revision.text:
'''Aaron Twapewa Johannes Mushimba''' (12 December 1946-31 August 2014) was a [[Namibia]]n businessperson. Described as a business mogul,<ref>[http://www.namibian.com.na/index.php?id=28&tx_ttnews%5btt_news%5d=72457&no_cache=1 Mushimba courts Namcor] [[The Namibian]], 14 September 2010</ref> Mushimba was involved with the trading of diamonds. He was linked to [[Belgian American]] diamond merchant [[Maurice Tempelsman]].<ref>[http://www.zimbabwesituation.com/oct28_2002.html]</ref> He was the chairperson of Namibian Investment Group [[PE Minerals]], which holds the mining rights to the [[Rosh Pinah]] mine in Namibia's [[ǁKaras Region]].<ref>[http://www.miningweekly.com/article/increased-namibian-ownership-of-rosh-pinah-mine-2008-08-15 Increased Namibian ownership of Rosh Pinah mine] [[Mining Weekly]], 15 August 2008</ref> He is the brother-in-law of the first Namibia's Founding President [[Sam Nujoma]].<ref name="NID">[http://www.nid.org.na/view_book_entry.php?book_id=120 Aaron Mushimba] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611174449/http://www.nid.org.na/view_book_entry.php?book_id=120 |date=June 11, 2011 }} Namibia Institute for Democracy</ref>
==History== Mushimba, who was the brother of President [[Sam Nujoma]]'s wife, [[Kovambo Nujoma]], was involved in the liberation struggle beginning in the early 1960s. As the national organiser for [[SWAPO]] inside the country, he was arrested and tortured several times by the [[apartheid]] authorities in the mid-1970s. In 1975 he was arrested in connection with the assassination of Ndonga Chief Filemon Elifas, the Chief Minister of the tribal [[Ovamboland|Ovambo]] Executive. Mushimba was sentenced to death but released on appeal in 1977 after it was found that the defense had leaked documents to the prosecution in his original trial. After his release he left for exile, where he acted as a 'fixer' for SWAPO, particularly concerning money matters. During the 1980s he was Deputy Treasurer on the SWAPO Politburo. His political track record and the fact that he was Nujoma's brother-in-law did not prevent him being detained by SWAPO in the late 1980s.
With independence, Mushimba played a dominant role in a number of business initiatives ranging from fishing through banking to construction. Several made newspaper headlines in the 1990s. He was chairman of Stocks and Stocks Namibia when the company built the [[Windhoek Country Club and Resort]]. The hotel's construction fell so far behind schedule that its launch event, the [[Miss Universe 1995|Miss Universe pageant of 1995]], had to be held with the complex only part-completed. By the end of the decade, the government owned the hotel after Stocks and Stocks failed to pay its debts. Stocks and Stocks also won contracts worth over N$300 million to build government office buildings in the 1990s. The government granted Mushimba's mining company, PE Minerals, the mineral rights for the [[Rosh Pinah mine|Rosh Pinah zinc mine]] in 1995. Following three years of uncertainty over the future of the mine, [[PE Minerals]] signed a partnership deal with the mine owners, [[Mittal Steel South Africa|Iscor]], at the end of 1998. Another company that Mushimba heads, Namibian Harvest Investments, bought the majority share in the struggling City Savings and Investment Bank in 2001.
Mushimba was reported to be acting as the representative of international diamond trader [[Maurice Tempelsman]], who in 2002 offered the government an interest free loan in return for keeping [[De Beers]]'exclusive marketing contract for NamDeb's diamonds. He has also emerged as a key player in Epia Investments, the empowerment company formed by Ohlthaver and List, the owners of [[Namibia Breweries Limited|Namibia Breweries]]. Mushimba has played a key role in several of Namibia's largest black empowerment deals.<ref name="NID"/>
Mushimba died on 31 August 2014 in a Cape Town hospital where he had been hospitalised for three weeks previous. According to his daughter Ujama, Mushimba was admitted for a back surgery, but suffered complications after the operation . He was 67.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Aaron Mushimba – struggle icon, politician and businessman (07 December 1946 – 31 August 2014) |newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]] |date=5 September 2014 |url=https://www.newera.com.na/2014/09/05/aaron-mushimba-struggle-icon-politician-and-businessman-07-december-1946-31-august-2014/}}</ref>

{{Peacock|date=December 2018}}{{wiktionary|acquihire}}
'''Acqui-hiring''' or '''Acq-hiring''' (a [[portmanteau]] of "acquisition" and "hiring") or '''talent acquisition''', is the process of [[Mergers and acquisitions|acquiring]] a company to [[Recruitment|recruit]] its employees, without necessarily showing an interest in its current products and services—or their continued operation.<ref name="Sullivan">{{cite web|url=http://www.eremedia.com/ere/acqui-hiring-a-powerful-recruiting-strategy-that-youve-never-heard-of//|title=Acqui-hiring: A Powerful Recruiting Strategy That You’ve Never Heard of |publisher=ERE.net |last=Sullivan|first=John|date=10 December 2012|accessdate=20 April 2013}}</ref><ref name="Yarow">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/why-so-many-startups-are-being-acqui-hired-2012-8|title=Why So Many Startups Are Being Acqui-Hired |last=Yarow|first=Jay|date=10 August 2012|work=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=20 April 2013}}</ref> "Some technology blogs call it being 'acqhired.' The companies doing the buying say it is a talent acquisition, and it typically comes with a price per head," the ''New York Times'' reported in a page-one story describing the phenomenon on May 17, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=For Buyers of Web Start-Ups, Quest to Corral Young Talent|last=Helft, Miguel|date=17 May 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/18/technology/18talent.html|publisher=New York Times, page 1|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref> The process of a talent acquisition also provides a relatively favorable [[exit strategy]] for employees with the prestige of being bought by a larger company, combined with the typical process of hiring.<ref name=atd-nosense>{{cite web|title=The Vanity of the "Acqhire": Why Do a Deal That Makes No Sense?|url=http://allthingsd.com/20120810/the-vanity-of-the-acqhire-why-do-a-deal-that-makes-no-sense/|publisher=All Things D|accessdate=23 May 2013}}</ref>
In September 2010, linguist [[Ben Zimmer]], in an article appearing on Visual Thesaurus, traced the derivation of the phrase to a blog post in May, 2005.<ref>{{cite web|title=Buzzword Watch: "Acq-hire"|last=Zimmer, Ben|date=29 September 2010|url=http://www.visualthesaurus.com/cm/wordroutes/buzzword-watch-acq-hire/|publisher=Visual Thesaurus|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
Acqui-hiring has become increasingly common in [[venture capital|VC]]-backed [[startup company|startup companies]], especially within the competitive [[technology]] sector; as of March 2013, [[Facebook]] was the largest performer of talent acquisitions, with 12 over the last five [[Fiscal year|fiscal quarters]]. [[Twitter]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google]] rank alongside Facebook as similarly major users of talent acquisitions.<ref name=ubj-acquihire>{{cite web|title=Facebook leads growing acqui-hire craze|url=http://upstart.bizjournals.com/money/loot/2013/03/28/facebook-leads-growing-acqui-hire-craze.html?page=all|publisher=Upstart Business Journal|accessdate=23 May 2013}}</ref>
Acqui-hiring is facilitated by [[Acquisourcing|acqui-sourcing]] - the process of identifying companies that agree to be acquired.
'''Why companies practice Acqui-hiring'''
There are various reasons why companies engage in acqui-hiring. These include helping to reduce the risk of litigation,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Coyle |first1=John F. |last2=Polsky |first2=Gregg D. |title=ACQUI-HIRING |journal=Duke Law Journal |date=November 2013 |volume=63 |issue=2 |page=301-317 |url=https://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=&httpsredir=1&article=3400&context=dlj}}</ref> reduce money expenditure when hiring a large group of employees,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Coyle |first1=John F. |last2=Polsky |first2=Gregg D. |title=ACQUI-HIRING |journal=Duke Law Journal |date=November 2013 |volume=63 |issue=2 |page=301-317 |url=https://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=&httpsredir=1&article=3400&context=dlj}}</ref> or hide the failures of start-up companies from the public.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bensona |first1=David |last2=Ziedonis |first2=Rosemarie H. |title=Corporate venture capital and the returns to acquiring portfolio companies |journal=Journal of Financial Economics |date=December 2010 |volume=98 |issue=3 |page=478-499 |doi=10.1016/j.jfineco.2010.07.003 |url=http://isiarticles.com/bundles/Article/pre/pdf/48229.pdf |accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref>
'''Is Acqui-hiring right for your firm?'''
While Acqui-hiring is a great modern that companies seem to be shifting to, one needs to consider whether their company is fit for the process. some of the factors that need to be put into consideration such as, the company should ensure that there is need tor a huge number of personnel before engaging in Aqui-hiring.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Chatterji |first1=Aaron |last2=Patro |first2=Arun |title=Dynamic Capabilities and Managing Human Capital |journal=Academy of Management Perspectives |date=29 Oct 2014 |volume=28 |issue=4 |url=https://journals.aom.org/doi/10.5465/amp.2013.0111 |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> There should also be an easy access to the pool of customers for the company that intends to engage in Acqui-hiring and finally when a comparatively large company intends to beat smaller companies to acquisition of employees.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Chatterji |first1=Aaron |last2=Patro |first2=Arun |title=Dynamic Capabilities and Managing Human Capital |journal=Academy of Management Perspectives |date=29 Oct 2014 |volume=28 |issue=4 |url=https://journals.aom.org/doi/10.5465/amp.2013.0111 |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=April 2018}} {{more footnotes|date=April 2018}} {{notability|1=Companies|date=September 2017}} }} '''Aetas (AΣtas)'''  is a South African [[e-commerce]] company headquartered in [[KwaZulu-Natal]], [[South Africa]]. Aetas develops Ready - to - Trade Online [[Startup company|start-up companies]] and e-commerce systems for individuals and companies.
Aetas was founded in 2015 in the small coastal town [[Amanzimtoti]], KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. The company claims they were the first registered company in South Africa to sell Ready-to-Trade online start-up companies. The company focuses on crowd participation.
== History == Aetas was founded in 2015 by Walter Paul van Zyl, after trying to open Aetas Online Campus (an online Campus that offered online short study courses).
In February 2016 Aetas launched an online boutique platform called Aetas Fashion Network. The platform helps individuals and companies to start their own online company by selling clothing and apparel online.
In 2017 Aetas Launched Aetas Mobile [[Mobile virtual network operator|MVNO]]. It is a South African mobile network service provider. The company offers consumers a wide range of prepaid, hybrid and postpaid products and services, including voice, data and messaging services. With its focus on affordable access and a money back incentive.
== Reception == Since its launch, Aetas has been well received by popular magazines such as [[Fast Company (magazine)|''Fast Company'']],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://issuu.com/fastcompanysa/docs/fc_june_2015/29|title="EVERYTHING A CEO NEEDS"|last=|first=|date=June 2015|website=Fast Company|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> who say "It's about allowing people from all walks of life the opportunity to run their own business-and run it well". The service was profiled in publications including ''Tech Smart'' magazine.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.techsmart.co.za/business/The-instant-CEO-Just-add-AETAS.html|title=" The Instant CEO:Just add Aetas"|last=|first=|date=25 May 2015|website=Tech Smart|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

Maha Juffali |parents = |relations = |website = }} '''Ahmed Abdullah Juffali''' (1924–1994) was a [[Saudi]] businessman and the founder of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]], one of Saudi Arabia's largest companies. ==Early life== Juffali was born in [[Mecca]] into "a prominent family" from [[Oneiza]] in [[Najd]].{{cite news|last1=Luqman|first1=Farouk|title=Ahmed Al-Juffali who supplied electricity to Jeddah residents|url=http://www.arabnews.com/ahmed-al-juffali-who-supplied-electricity-jeddah-residents|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=arabnews|date=1 February 2013}} ==Career== Juffali was the founder of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]], one of Saudi Arabia's largest companies.{{cite web|title=The Al Juffali family|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/arabian-business-rich-list-2010-367763.html?view=profile&itemid=367819|website=arabianbusiness|accessdate=11 November 2015}}{{cite book|author=Stig Stenslie|title=Regime Stability in Saudi Arabia: The Challenge of Succession|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-g81rF4Zga4C&pg=PA60|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=21 August 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-51157-8|page=60}} The company was founded in 1946, by Ahmed and his brothers Ebrahim and Ali.{{cite web|title=Who We Are|url=http://www.juffali.com/aboutus/1|website=juffali|accessdate=18 November 2015}} He entered into partnerships with companies including IBM, Siemens, Ericsson, Mercedes Benz, Michelin, Massey Ferguson, Electrolux, Kelvinator, Carrier, Dow Chemicals, DuPont and Butler. He was a member of [[The 1001: A Nature Trust]].{{cite web|title=1001 Club from Project for the Exposure of Hidden Institutions Incomplete membership list|url=http://www.newsfollowup.com/1001club.htm|website=newsfollowup|accessdate=18 November 2015}} ==Personal life== Juffali died in 1994 and was survived by his wife, Suad Al Husseini Al Juffali, three sons and a daughter. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Juffali, Ahmed}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:1994 deaths]] [[Category:Juffali family|Ahmed]] [[Category:People from Mecca]] [[Category:People from Jeddah]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]]

{{Korean name|Ahn}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox politician | name = Ahn Cheol-soo | native_name = {{nobold|안철수}} | native_name_lang = ko | image = File:안철수 의원의 깜짝 방문 (cropped).jpg | caption = | office = Chairman of the [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] | term_start = 27 August 2017 | term_end = 13 February 2018 | predecessor = [[Park Jie-won]] | successor = ''Position disestablished'' | term_start1 = 2 February 2016 | term_end1 = 29 June 2016 | alongside1 = [[Chun Jung-bae]] | predecessor1 = ''Position established'' | successor1 = [[Park Jie-won]] | prececessor1 = [Park Jie-won]] | office2 = Member of the [[National Assembly of South Korea|National Assembly]] | constituency2 = [[Seoul]] [[Nowon District|Nowon]] C | term_start2 = 25 April 2013 | term_end2 = 15 April 2017 | predecessor2 = [[Roh Hoe-chan]] | successor2 = Kim Seong-hwan (2018) | office3 = Chairman of the [[New Politics Alliance for Democracy]] | term_start3 = 26 March 2014 | term_end3 = 31 July 2014 | alongside3 = [[Kim Han-gil]] | predecessor3 = ''Position established'' | successor3 = [[Moon Jae-in]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|02|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Miryang]], [[South Gyeongsang Province]], [[South Korea]] | nationality = [[South Korea]]n | ethnicity = [[Koreans|Korean]] | known_for = V3 ([[antivirus software]]) | alma_mater = [[Seoul National University]]
[[University of Pennsylvania]] | employer = | occupation = Physician
Professor
Software entrepreneur | years_active = 2012–present | party = [[Bareunmirae Party]] (2018-) | otherparty = [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] (2016–2018)
[[New Politics Alliance for Democracy|NPAD]] (2014–15) | title = | boards = | spouse = Kim Mi-kyung | children = 1 daughter | signature = Ahn Cheol-Soo signature.svg | website = |allegiance = {{flag|South Korea|1984}} |branch = {{Flagicon image|Naval jack of South Korea.svg|size=23px}} [[Republic of Korea Navy]] |serviceyears = 1992–1994 |rank = [[File:대위.JPG|25px]] [[Daewi|Lieutenant (Korean: Daewi)]] | footnotes = {{Cite web|url=http://www.ahnlab.co.kr/company/site/eng/pr/founder_retire.jsp |title=AhnLab |publisher=AhnLab |date=2002-07-08 |accessdate=2010-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722132936/http://www.ahnlab.co.kr/company/site/eng/pr/founder_retire.jsp |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}[http://www.koreafocus.or.kr/design2/interview/view.asp?volume_id=82&content_id=102446&category=J ''Ahn Chul-soo: “Korea needs horizontal thinking to make a Nintendo game player.”''] at [[Korea Foundation]].}} {{Infobox Korean name | hangul = {{linktext|안|철|수}} | hanja = {{linktext|安|哲|秀}} | rr = An Cheol-su | mr = An Ch'ŏlsu }} '''Ahn Cheol-soo''' ({{ko-hhrm|안철수}} {{IPA-ko|an tɕʰʌl.s͈u|}}; born 26 February 1962) is a [[South Korea]]n politician, physician, and software entrepreneur. A two-time former presidential election candidate in [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012]] and [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|2017]], Ahn is currently the [[Bareunmirae Party]]'s candidate for the [[Seoul]] [[Mayor of Seoul|mayorship]].{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3046505|title=Ahn Cheol-soo declares bid for Seoul mayor|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2018-04-05}} He ran as an independent candidate for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|presidential election in 2012]], but withdrew a month before the election took place to support [[Moon Jae-in]] whom he ran against in 2017 as the [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] nominee. He was a founding co-leader and the party leader of the People's Party until his party and [[Bareun Party]] merged as [[Bareunmirae Party]] in February 2018. Prior to politics, Ahn founded [[AhnLab, Inc.]], an [[antivirus software]] company, in 1995. He was chairman of the board and [[Chief Learning Officer]] of AhnLab until September 2012, and remains the company's largest stakeholder. Prior to entering politics, Ahn served as dean of the Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology at [[Seoul National University]] until September 2012. ==Early life and education== Ahn was born on 26 February 1962, in [[Miryang]], [[South Korea]], while his father was on military service there; he subsequently moved with his family to [[Busan]], where he grew up.{{cite news|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/555525.html|title=The vetting of Ahn Cheol-soo|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=12 October 2012|accessdate=18 April 2016}} Ahn was not an academic child but had number academic hobbies such as reading.http://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=109&aid=0002032901 He received his Doctor of Medicine (MD), Master of Science (MS), and Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) degrees in [[physiology]] from [[Seoul National University]] between 1980 and 1991. He became the youngest chief of professors at [[Dankook University]] medical college at 27 years of age, marking his first career as a medical doctor.{{Cite news|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/09/113_94248.html|title=Who is Ahn Cheol-soo|date=2011-09-05|work=koreatimes|access-date=2017-03-29|language=en}} Ahn met his wife whilst in university.{{Cite news|url=http://news.jkn.co.kr/article/news/20090618/3355840.htm|title=‘무릎팍도사’ 출연 안철수, “부인과는 유명한 캠퍼스 커플, 프러포즈는…”|last=재경일보|date=2009-06-18|work=재경일보|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Whilst working as a graduate student pursuing his MD, Ahn began to gain an interest in computer software as a hobby, in particular, [[antivirus software]]. Ahn soon began working on his own antivirus software after he was confronted with a virus that was mass-infecting computers in Korea. Ahn was soon infected with the same virus and reverse engineered the virus in an attempt to erase it from his disk drive which was successful. The program he wrote to help get rid of the virus was eventually called "Vaccine"{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsen.com/news_view.php?uid=200906180048251001|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} which Ahn distributed for free. == Business Career == === AhnLab, Inc === After finishing military service as a medical officer in the [[Republic of Korea Navy|South Korean navy]], and leaving behind his career in the medical profession, Cheol-soo went on to establish his venture company [[AhnLab, Inc.|AhnLab, Inc]] in March 1995 after being advised by a software company official to do so.{{Cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=102&oid=029&aid=0001985929|title=안철수 KAIST 교수, 17일 무릎팍 도사 출연|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Ahn had previously attempted to distribute V3 via Samsung's brand though Samsung rejected Ahn's offer.{{Cite web|url=http://artsnews.mk.co.kr/news/29862|title=안철수, 1000만 불 인수제의 거절한 이유!! {{!}} 아츠뉴스|website=artsnews.mk.co.kr|access-date=2018-05-10}} Ahn, not knowing how to run a business at first, struggled for the first several years.{{Cite web|url=https://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=143&aid=0001993990|title=‘무릎팍도사’ 안철수, 반쪽짜리 감동|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Whilst managing the company, Ahn was also attempting to get a master's degree in engineering at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], where he graduated in 1997.{{Cite web|url=http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/society/201103/h2011031821075622020.htm|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Ahn eventually received a $10 million offer from US software giant, [[McAfee]]민도식, 나를 확바꾸는 실천 독서법 북포스 155페이지 '1997년 직원들에게 안철수연구소를 맡겨둔채 미국에서 유학하며 실리콘벨리에 머물던 중 현재 경쟁회사 맥아피에게 1천만달러 제안 받았지만 거절' and Ahn met with [[John McAfee]] personally. McAfee was struggling to expand into South Korea due to AhnLab, Inc and wanted to purchase the company in an attempt to monopolize the anti-virus software market in South Korea. Ahn rejected the offer because, despite the AhnLab, Inc struggling, selling the company would lead to widespread redundancies.{{Cite news|url=http://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=015&aid=0002085972|title='무릎팍도사' 출연 안철수, 온화한 카리스마로 시청자 압도|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.hkn24.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=27942|title=무릎팍 안철수 “외국회사 1000만불 매각제의 단호히 거절” - 헬스코리아뉴스|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} In 1999, the company began to run a surplus after the CIH virus became widespread in Korea and people needed to buy V3 to protect against it.{{Cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=101&oid=047&aid=0001963116|title=안철수 "정치할 생각 있냐고요?"|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} By the end of 1999, AhnLab, Inc became the second biggest computer security company in South Korea.{{Cite news|url=http://www.asiatoday.co.kr/view.php?key=258456|title=‘무릎팍도사’ 출연 안철수, “한국의 빌게이츠(?)...너무 과분해”|work=종합일간지 : 신문/웹/모바일 등 멀티 채널로 국내외 실시간 뉴스와 수준 높은 정보를 제공|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} The same company later became the largest computer security company in South Korea,[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2009/10/258_40800.html ''AhnLab Looks to Perform in International Stage''] at ''[[The Korea Times|Korea Times]]''.[http://www.koreaittimes.com/story/5502/ahnlab-considers-overseas-ma ''AhnLab Considers Overseas M&A''] at ''Korea IT Times''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/20/world/asia/new-voice-in-south-korean-politics-enters-presidential-race.html|title=New Voice in South Korean Politics, Ahn Cheol-soo, Enters Presidential Race|last=Gladstone|first=Rick|date=2012-09-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-29|last2=Lee|first2=Su-hyun|issn=0362-4331}} and was included in annual lists of Korea's most admired companies by Korea Management Association Consulting between 2004 and 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.kmac.co.kr/certify/certify_01a_1.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304024034/http://www.kmac.co.kr/certify/certify_01a_1.asp |archivedate=2016-03-04 }} {{ko icon}}[http://www.asiae.co.kr/uhtml/read.php?idxno=2008022017371847343 ''AhnLab, "The Korea's Most Admired company" Consecutive 5 years''] at ''Asia Economy'' (2008.02.20). {{ko icon}}{{Cite web|url=http://kr.ahnlab.com/company/eng/about/milestone.jsp|title=AhnLab|date=|publisher=Kr.ahnlab.com|accessdate=2010-01-22}}[http://news.mk.co.kr/outside/view.php?year=2008&no=92321 ''Samsung Electronics Most Admired Company in Korea: Survey''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723173328/http://news.mk.co.kr/outside/view.php?year=2008&no=92321 |date=23 July 2011 }} at ''Maeil Business Newspaper'' & mk.co.kr[http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/culture/book/297104.html Book review "''세상에서 가장 안전한 이름 안철수 연구소''"] at ''[[The Hankyoreh]]''. {{ko icon}} He resigned as CEO in 2005 and served as chairman of the board until 2012. Ahn revealed that [[John McAfee]] once suggested it would acquire AhnLab for $10,000,000 but rejected the offer. He mentioned patriotic reasons about the decision saying that selling AhnLab might allow a foreign firm to dominate the Korean market. === Later life and education === Ahn became an outside director of [[POSCO]] in 2005, and from 2010 to 2011 was chairman of the company. Ahn was awarded an Executive Master of Business Administration (EMBA) degree from the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School]] (San Francisco campus) in 2008. He then became a professor at [[KAIST]] in 2008, and later in the beginning of 2011 became the Dean of the Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology at [[Seoul National University]]. ==Political career== ===Entry into politics === Since 2006, Ahn had been offered places in the main political parties but was constantly denied any chance to run as an independent due to opposing factions. In early September 2011, speculation spread that Ahn would enter politics by competing in the 26 October Seoul mayoral by-election. The Democratic Party and Liberty Korea Party attempted to recruit Ahn for the mayoral by-election though they failed due to Ahn feeling like he, and many other voters, had become disenfranchised with the main two choices.{{Cite web|url=http://www.imbc.com/broad/tv/culture/sisa2580/vod/index.html?kind=image&progCode=1000845100520100000&pagesize=5&pagenum=1&cornerFlag=1&ContentTypeID=1&ProgramGroupID=0|title=다시보기 {{!}} 시사매거진 2580|website=www.imbc.com|language=ko|access-date=2018-05-10}} Ahn eventually made an announcement, denouncing the opposition and ruling party{{Cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20110905n06506|title=안철수, "야권과 단일화 얼마든지 고려할 수 있다"|website=네이트뉴스|language=ko-KR|access-date=2018-05-10}} and saying he was not sure on his candidacy, deciding to watch the polls before making a choice though he shared the sentiment that he felt like it'd take a lot of work to help Seoul, saying "ten years of work" would be needed to help the city.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20110905n07503|title=안철수 "윤여준이 기획자? 그건 언론의 오보"|website=네이트뉴스|language=ko-KR|access-date=2018-05-10}} Analysts stated that if positioned as an independent, Ahn would attract a degree of support from those disaffected by mainstream political parties in the wake of corruption allegations and continuing policy failures. Ahn's polling was higher than other potential candidates, at 35% with second place coming in at 17%.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20110905n02597|title=안철수, 서울시장 보선 여론조사서 압도적 선두|website=네이트뉴스|language=ko-KR|access-date=2018-05-10}} His approval rating was subsequently polled afterwards, reaching over 50%.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mediatoday.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=97232|title=조국 "안철수에 큰박수" 진중권 "과연 인물"|last=미디어오늘|date=2011-09-06|work=미디어오늘|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Ahn eventually didn't run despite his positive poll ratings{{Cite news|url=http://v.media.daum.net/v/20110907084056110|title="아무 조건 없습니다" 안철수 깨끗한 양보|date=2011-09-07|work=다음 뉴스|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} instead endorsing [[Park Won-soon]] who went on to win the by-election.{{Cite news|url=http://v.media.daum.net/v/20110907024716274|title=박원순, 안철수 지지율 흡수 여부가 변수|date=2011-09-07|work=다음 뉴스|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Park's win has been attributed to Ahn's endorsement due to centrist voters moving to Park's side after the endorsement.{{Cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=032&aid=0002162450|title=박원순 ‘안철수 지지’ 업고 나경원과 오차내 접전|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} He alluded to standing as a presidential candidate in his 2012 book ''Thoughts of Ahn Cheol-Soo''.{{cite news|last=Yeong-doo|first=Kang|title=Ahn Cheol-soo to announce his candidancy virtually|url=http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/politics/2012/07/19/0502000000AKR20120719102051001.HTML?template=5565|accessdate=19 July 2012 |newspaper=Yonhapnews |date=19 July 2012}} ===First presidential campaign (2012)=== On 19 September 2012, at 3 p.m. [[Korea Standard Time]], Ahn held a press conference and announced his intention to run for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]]. This announcement came after months of speculation on whether or not Ahn was going to run for the presidency. The South Korean presidential election was to be held on 19 December 2012. In an address that lasted around 20 minutes, Ahn spent a considerable amount of time explaining how he came to the decision to run for President of the Republic of Korea, quoting the people he had met while exploring his candidacy, who had expressed their desire for a "new politics". Ahn at one point showed to be polling stronger than [[Moon Jae-in]], with a few polls showing he could win against [[Park Geun-hye]], the candidate who would go on to win the election. On 23 November 2012, at 8:20 p.m. KST, Ahn announced that he would drop out of the race,http://news.naver.com/main/president2012/news/read.nhn?mid=hot&sid1=154&cid=909465&iid=39207146&oid=003&aid=0004843794&ptype=011 endorsing Moon Jae-in, the Democratic United Party presidential candidate. ===Early Assembly career (2013–2016)=== On 11 March 2013, Ahn announced that he would run for a seat in the [[National Assembly of South Korea]] as an independent candidate in the by-election in the district of [[Seoul]] [[Nowon-gu|Nowon]] C. He won the election on 24 April, entering his first elected office.{{cite news|title=전국 12개 재보선 개표 마무리…安·金·李 당선|url=http://news1.kr/articles/1105911|accessdate=24 April 2013|newspaper=News1}} In May 2013, he launched a new think tank named Policy Network Tomorrow.{{cite news|title=안철수 싱크탱크 출범, 신당 창당 궤도에 올라|url=http://www.newdaily.co.kr/news/article.html?no=155844|accessdate=25 May 2013|newspaper=Newdaily}} ==== New Politics Alliance for Democracy Chairmanship (2014) ==== Having entered the Assembly, Ahn began to explore the creation of a new party, which was provisionally named the New Political Vision Party on the basis of public surveys.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2985037|title=Ahn’s party to establish new name at gathering|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=17 February 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}} On 26 March 2014, however, while the party was in the process of being set up, Ahn merged his faction with the liberal Democratic Party to form the [[New Politics Alliance for Democracy]] (NPAD), becoming co-chairman of the new party alongside [[Kim Han-gil]].{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2985728|title=Political shocker as DP, Ahn Cheol-soo merge|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=3 March 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://english.donga.com/List/3/all/26/407931/1|title=Democratic Party, Ahn Cheol-soo agree to create new party|newspaper=[[The Dong-A Ilbo]]|date=3 March 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Ahn and Kim both resigned from their position three months later in July following the new party's disappointing performance in [[South Korean by-elections, 2014|by-elections that year]], which had seen the liberals lose a seat in [[Jeolla]] to conservatives for the first time in 26 years.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2992867|title=Co-chairmen quit amid election rubble|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=1 August 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}} ==== Defection from the NPAD (2015) ==== Ahn remained in the NPAD, but came into increasing conflict with Moon Jae-in, who had taken over sole leadership of the party after his resignation, and the "pro-Roh" faction that Moon represented. In December 2015, Ahn issued an ultimatum to Moon demanding that a convention be held at the beginning of 2016 to elect a new party leader. Moon rejected the demand.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=3012565|title=NPAD’s Moon rejects Ahn demand|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=9 December 2015|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Ahn then left the NPAD along with a range of other lawmakers opposed to Moon, including Kim Han-gil.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/12/116_193056.html|title=Ahn Cheol-soo calls it quits with NPAD|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=13 December 2015|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Announcing that he would form a new party, he subsequently joined forces with [[Chun Jung-bae]], who had left the party earlier in the year,{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150914001156|title=Party feud erodes Moon’s leadership|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=12 April 2016}} to form the [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] in January 2016.{{cite news|url=http://tbsefm.seoul.kr/eNews/news.do?method=efmNewsInfo&idx_800=2143018&typ_800=N |title=Ahn Cheol-Soo, Chun Jung-Bae To Create New Party |publisher=TBS eFM |date=25 January 2016 |accessdate=12 April 2016}}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Moon resigned as leader after Ahn's defection, describing his experience as "a series of difficult days without a single one of respite".{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/728307.html|title=Moon Jae-in steps down as leader of The Minjoo Party of Korea|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=28 January 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} ===People's Party (2016–2018)=== Ahn positioned the new [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] as an anti-establishment centrist force, attracting support from both political wings.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_201981.html|title=Ahn's popularity baffles parties|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=5 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} He labeled the remaining NPAD "anachronistic progressives",{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160118000971|title=Debate over first President Rhee reignites|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=18 January 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} and accused contemporary Korean politicians of lacking policies beyond "short-term gimmicks".{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/emanuel-pastreich/the-bernie-sanders-of-kor_b_9211944.html|title=The Bernie Sanders of Korea? An Interview With Ahn Cheol-soo|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=11 February 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} In the lead-up to the [[South Korean legislative election, 2016|April 13 parliamentary election]], he came into conflict with his co-leader Chun and other members of the party after [[Kim Chong-in]], the interim leader of the Democratic Party, the NPAD's successor, called for the two parties to form an electoral alliance. Kim Han-gil and Ahn's co-leader Chun both supported the plan, but Ahn rejected any prospect of an alliance with his former party.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_199827.html|title=Ahn stumbling on internal feud|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=7 March 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} The proposal was ultimately scotched, with Kim Han-gil withdrawing from the upcoming election in protest.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_200609.html |title=Rep. Kim not to run in April elections |newspaper=[[The Korea Times]] |date=17 March 2016 |accessdate=15 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424133619/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_200609.html |archivedate=24 April 2016 |df= }} In the event, the People's Party performed better than anticipated, coming second in [[party-list proportional representation|party-list]] voting and winning 38 seats overall, including 23 of the 28 districts in the liberal stronghold of Jeolla.{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/739721.html|title=In liberal stronghold, voters give main opposition party a lashing|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} The People's Party held the balance of power in the new Assembly, establishing a [[multi-party system|three-party system]].{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160413000614|title=Minority People's Party steals show: Ahn’s Party holds balance of power as three party system dawns|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Ahn was credited for the victory, which was seen as giving him a position as [[kingmaker]] and support for contesting [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|the presidential elections in the following year]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-14/software-tycoon-turns-political-kingmaker-in-korean-stalemate|title=Software Tycoon Turns Political Kingmaker in Korea Stalemate|publisher=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202545.html|title=Attention to shift to 2017 presidential race|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=13 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Following the election, Ahn rejected continued calls to regroup with the Minjoo Party, stating that "it would be inappropriate to speak of politically realigning at this point in time". He added that the People's Party would not be "a mere tie-breaking third party, but ... a new opinion leader in parliamentary affairs".{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160417000276|title=Ahn gestures at moving onto presidential race|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=17 April 2016|accessdate=18 April 2016}} ==== Second presidential campaign and defeat (2017) ==== Ahn was widely known to be a likely contender for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|2017 South Korean presidential election]]. He was selected as the People's Party's nominee,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/14/world/asia/south-korea-election-ahn-cheol-soo.html|title=South Korea Election Turns Into 2-Way Race as Dark Horse Surges|last=Sang-hun|first=Choe|date=2017-04-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-15|issn=0362-4331}} defeating [[Sohn Hak-kyu]] and [[Park Joo-sun]].http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=079&aid=0003072580 Despite rapid increase in opinion polling which briefly bypassed [[Moon Jae-in|Moon Jae-In]], Ahn floundered in TV debates that led to his loss finishing third in a field of five total candidates.'{{Cite news|url=http://www.ytn.co.kr/_ln/0101_201705032206263984|title=Ahn And Hong Exchanges 2nd Place In Polling}} ==== Return of party chairmanship (2017-2018) ==== The underperformance of his presidential campaign and a party scandal that found People's Party members fabricating evidence to smear Moon Jae-in's campaign led Ahn to declare in July 2017 to both apologize and take a step back from politics in "self-reflection." He returned a month later to run, and later win, the party chairmanship.{{Cite web|url=http://mengnews.joins.com/view.aspx?aId=3037660|title=Ahn Cheol-soo hails his comeback as People’s Party head|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2017-09-15}} === Bareunmirae Party (2018-present) === As head of the People's Party, Ahn was a strong advocate for merging with the center-right Bareun Party. The two leaders of the respective parties, Ahn and former presidential contender [[Yoo Seong-min|Yoo Seung-min]], pushed forward with the merger which was completed in February 2018. Although Yoo retained a leadership position within the new party and Ahn stepped down from any leadership role, as of March 2018 took on the role of leading the party's talent recruiting committee - a formal position speculated to signal his preparation to run for the Seoul mayorship later in the year.{{Cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20180316000791|title=Parties ready for Seoul mayoral election|last=Herald|first=The Korea|date=2018-03-16|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}} ==== Seoul Mayorship campaign (2018) ==== ==Political positions== === "New Politics" === Ahn has stated that he considers [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] to be a role model, and has referred to himself as the [[Bernie Sanders]] of Korea.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/emanuel-pastreich/the-bernie-sanders-of-kor_b_9211944.html|title=The Bernie Sanders of Korea? An Interview With Ahn Cheol-soo|newspaper=The World Post|date=11 February 2016|accessdate=17 February 2016}} He supports an increased [[capital gains tax]], higher public welfare spending, and a cautious approach to free trade agreements. === Centrism === Ahn has also made appeals to conservatives, however, and has associated the People's Party with "reformative" currents of Korean conservatism.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202138.html|title=Ahn backs Yoo to woo conservatives|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=7 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} In September 2012, Ahn visited the graves of [[Syngman Rhee]], [[Park Chung-hee]], and [[Kim Dae-jung]]. Park and Rhee are often praised by Korean conservatives, and Kim by liberals. Ahn stated at the time that it would be "hypocritical to paint half the people as enemies and at the same time call for 'unity{{'"}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/552749.html|title=Ahn visits National Cemetery in first political act|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=21 September 2012|accessdate=17 April 2016}} Ahn has been considered "more palatable for conservative voters" in part due to his business background. === National security (THAAD) === Ahn was among the first who opposed the American deployment of the [[Terminal High Altitude Area Defense]] system, commonly referred to as THAAD, alongside Moon Jae-in. However, he changed his stance suggesting it was "irresponsible" for any future president to reverse an agreement already made between the United States and Korea. === LGBT rights === Ahn has stated he opposes the legalization of [[same-sex marriage]], although in a more detailed article on broadcasting network SBS' website, he said that same-sex marriage needs to be achieved through social discussion.{{cn|date=February 2018}} ==Philanthropy== In December 2011, Ahn has expressed his willingness to donate half of his shares in AhnLab for the education of children from low-income families. He owns 37.1 percent of AhnLab shares, and as of 9 December 2011, the value of the shares to be donated is about 250 billion won ($218 million).{{cite news |first = Gwang-bin (광빈) |last = Lee (이) |script-title=ko:안철수 기부주식 2천500억원 넘어 |date = 2011-12-11 |url = http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2011/12/10/0200000000AKR20111210045600001.HTML |work = Yonhap News |accessdate = 2011-12-11 |language = Korean}} ==Legal problems== In September 2012, Ahn made a public apology as reports surfaced that his wife evaded taxes by under-pricing a 2001 apartment she bought worth ₩450 million to ₩250 million, thus reducing the acquisition and registration taxes by up to ₩10 million. However, a statement by the Korea Taxpayers' Association claimed that the "down contract" was in accordance with trade customs and thus not unlawful due to flaws in the local tax law between 1996 and 2005.{{Cite news |last=Bae |first=Hyun-jung |title=Ahn apologizes for wife's tax-dodging |newspaper=Korea Herald |publication-place=Seoul |date=28 September 2012 |ref=harv |postscript= }} == Personal life == In 1988 he married Kim Mi-kyung, who is currently a professor at the Seoul National University College of Medicine. Ahn has a daughter with Kim.http://news.mk.co.kr/newsRead.php?year=2012&no=610838 {{ko icon}} ==Bibliography== * 2012. {{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Andrew Geddis leading sauce anglais in 1.jpg|thumbnail|300px| As chairman of the [[Royal Western India Turf Club]] (1931–1939) leading in Sauce Anglais winner of the Juhu Plate, April ‘45 ridden by his daughter ]] --> '''Andrew Geddis''' (July 1886 – 23 February 1976) was a leading business man and sports enthusiast in [[Bombay]] in the decades leading up to independence. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:D M & DFC Poona Races Aug '43 1.jpg|thumb|left|350px|With daughter, Margaret and future son-in-law [[Donald Callander]] at Poona Races in Aug '43]] -->
==Biography== He was Chairman of the [[Royal Western India Turf Club]] (1931–1939) and instigated Mumbai Races's A.Geddis Plate. His extensive business interests included a directorship of the [[Bank of India]] Ltd and co-founding Geoffrey Manners & Co. Ltd., which became a leading distributor and manufacturer of Consumer Healthcare products and Pharmaceuticals across India until its amalgamation in April 2003 with the [[Wyeth]] Corporation, formerly known as American Home Products (AHP),one of the largest [[pharmaceutical company|pharmaceutical companies]] in the world.
He left [[Bruntsfield|Bruntsfield Place]] in [[Edinburgh]] for Bombay in 1907 to work for James Finlay & Co. Ltd. and went on to become extensively involved in the [[Ahmedabad textile industry]] becoming a Director of the Ahmedabad Jubilee Spinning & Manufacturing Co., Ltd. and the Ahmedabad Manufacturing & Calico Printing Co. Ltd., as well as Director of the India Cotton Association and the Chairman of Mill Owners' Mutual Insurance Association Ltd from its inception. [[File:Kamal mahal in 1940.jpg|thumbnail|350px|left| Kamal Mahal atop [[Cumballa Hill]] in 1940]]
His wider interests included, as well as co-founding Geoffrey Manners & Co. Ltd., directorships of the Tata Hydroelectric Power Supply Co., Ltd., the Indian Radio & Cable Communications Co.and the Bank of India Ltd. He was a member of the G. 1. P. Railway Advisory committee for 13 years and was appointed to the Board of Trustees for the Bombay Port trust in 1920.. A keen horse racing enthusiast, as well as his chairmanship of the Western India Turf Club was also Chairman of the Turf Club House, Poona. Other interests included being Chairman of the Bombay Scottish Orphanage Society and Chairman of the Caledonia Society of Bombay.
On arrival in India he stayed in the [[Pali Hill]] ''Chummery''. After his marriage to Jean Gunn, daughter of Dr [[Alexander Gunn (doctor)|Alexander Gunn]] of Edinburgh in 1915, he moved to Dharbanga Masions on [[Cumballa Hill]] before finally moving to the fourth floor apartment on the left below the penthouse in the iconic art deco Kamal Mahal building,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/High-life-Flat-on-Carmichael-Rd-fetches-Rs-33-cr-/articleshow/5875055.cms|title=High life: Flat on Carmichael Rd fetches Rs 33 cr" : Times of India, Apr 30, 2010 | work=The Times Of India | date=30 April 2010}}</ref> originally called Sethna House, on [[Carmichael Road]] in South Mumbai, which together with the adjacent [[Altamont Road]] was rated the tenth dearest address in the world in a in 2009 survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wealth-bulletin.com/home/content/2451423982 |title=Wealth Holding Page |publisher=Wealth-bulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2009-09-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420053915/http://www.wealth-bulletin.com/home/content/2451423982 |archivedate=2010-04-20 |df= }}</ref> He also had a beach house at [[Juhu]].

{{Infobox film | name = Big Business | image = Bigbusinessposter.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Jim Abrahams]] | producer = Michael Peyser
Steve Tisch | writer = Dori Pierson
Marc Reid Rubel | starring ={{Plainlist| * [[Bette Midler]] * [[Lily Tomlin]] }} | music = [[Lee Holdridge]] | cinematography = [[Dean Cundey]] | editing = [[Harry Keramidas]] | studio = [[Touchstone Pictures]]
[[Silver Screen Partners III]] | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Buena Vista Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1988|6|10}} | runtime = 97 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $20 million | gross = $40,150,487{{Mojo title|bigbusiness}} | Co-Producer = Bonnie Bruckheimer }} '''''Big Business''''' is a 1988 American [[comedy film]] starring [[Bette Midler]] and [[Lily Tomlin]] (each playing two roles). The movie revolves around two sets of [[Twin#Monozygotic (identical) twins|identical female twins]] mismatched at birth, with one of each pair ending in a wealthy urban family (the Sheltons) and the other in a poor rural family (the Ratliffs). It was produced by [[Touchstone Pictures]], with the plot loosely based on ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' (1589–1594) by [[William Shakespeare]]. The film co-stars [[Fred Ward]], [[Edward Herrmann]], [[Joe Grifasi]], and [[Seth Green]], as well as siblings [[Michael Gross (actor)|Michael Gross]] and [[Mary Gross]]. Directed by [[Jim Abrahams]], critical reaction to the film as a whole was generally lukewarm. Midler received an [[American Comedy Award]] in the category Funniest Actress in a Motion Picture for her performance, in 1989.{{cite web|title=Awards for ''Big Business''|work=iMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094739/awards|accessdate=2009-01-29}} ==Plot== In 1948, wealthy businessman Hunt Shelton and his pregnant wife are lost in rural [[West Virginia]] when Mrs. Shelton goes into labor near the town of Jupiter Hollow. At the local hospital, they are turned away, because it is exclusively for employees of Hollowmade, the local furniture maker. Mr. Shelton purchases the company on the spot, and Mrs. Shelton is then admitted. The Ratliffs, an impoverished couple, arrive moments later with Mrs. Ratliff also in labor. Both women give birth to twin girls, and the elderly nurse attending the doctor confuses and mixes up the sets of twins. Mr. Ratliff overhears the Sheltons deciding to name their daughters Rose and Sadie, and suggests the same names to his wife. Forty years later, the Shelton sisters are now co-chairwomen of Moramax in [[New York City]], a conglomerate that is the successor to their father's business interests. Sadie Shelton is focused on her career to the detriment of her family, while Rose Shelton wishes for a simpler life in the country. As part of her business plan, Sadie plans to sell Hollowmade, but must get stockholders' approval to proceed. In Jupiter Hollow, Rose Ratliff has risen to the position of forewoman at the Hollowmade Factory, and is also very career-driven. Meanwhile, Sadie Ratliff has always felt misplaced in rural life, and wishes for a more sophisticated life in a big city. Rose discovers Moramax's plans to sell Hollowmade, and makes plans to travel to New York City to stop the sale. Wanting to see the city, Sadie agrees to join her sister. While Sadie Shelton makes plans for the shareholders' meeting, she learns from her employee Graham Sherbourne that "R. Ratliff" plans to come to New York with his sister to stop the sale. Sadie orders Sherbourne to locate "R. Ratliff" to prevent them from appearing at the meeting. A series of mixups at [[JFK Airport]] leaves the Shelton sisters stranded while the prospective buyer of Hollowmade, Mr. Fabio Alberici, takes their limousine back to the [[Plaza Hotel]] with the Ratliff sisters. The Ratliffs are checked into the Sheltons' suite, and the Sheltons take the suite next door, leading to a series of near-misses between the four sisters, and the men who are pursuing them romantically. In the meantime, Graham and his assistant/boyfriend assume that a visitor from Jupiter Hollow, Rose Ratliff's beau Roone Dimmick, is actually "R. Ratliff." All sisters discover their mixup in the lobby bathroom. After Sadie Shelton acts like she will call off the Hollowmade sale, Rose Ratliff calls her out on the strip mining plans. Rose Shelton then realizes that Sadie has been lying to her, and helps the Ratliffs trap her in the broom closet. Rose Ratliff sits outside the broom closet to keep Sadie Shelton trapped, while Rose Shelton and Sadie Ratliff attend the shareholders' meeting and stop the sale of Hollowmade. Both sets of twins later leave the Plaza hotel with their newfound loves. ==Cast== {{Cast listing| * [[Bette Midler]] — Sadie Shelton/Sadie Ratliff * [[Lily Tomlin]] — Rose Ratliff/Rose Shelton * [[Fred Ward]] — Roone Dimmick * [[Michael Gross (actor)|Michael Gross]] — Dr. Jay Marshall * [[Edward Herrmann]] — Graham Sherbourne * [[Barry Primus]] — Michael * [[Michele Placido]] — Fabio Alberici * [[Seth Green]] — Jason * [[Daniel Gerroll]] — Chuck * [[John Hancock (actor)|John Hancock]] — Harlan * [[Deborah Rush]] — Binky Shelton * [[Nicolas Coster]] — Hunt Shelton * [[J. C. Quinn]] — Garth Ratliff * [[Joe Grifasi]] — Desk Clerk * [[John Vickery (actor)|John Vickery]] — Hotel Manager * [[Mary Gross]] — Judy * [[Carmen Argenziano]] - Board Member * [[Chick Hearn]] — as Himself * [[Don Pierson]] - Screenwriter * [[Marc Reid Rubel]] - Screenwriter * [[Shirley Mitchell]] - Stockholder }} ==Production== [[File:Plaza Hotel May 2010.JPG|thumb|right|The Plaza and its [[Modernist architecture|International Modern style]] neighbors as seen in the film.]] The movie was originally written for [[Barbra Streisand]] (Midler's role) and [[Goldie Hawn]] (Tomlin's role). The plot is a coincidental{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} and playful combination of three previously recognizable stories: Aesop's ''[[The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse]]'', Mark Twain's ''[[The Prince and the Pauper]]'', and Shakespeare's ''[[Comedy of Errors]]''. The production company could not get the rights to film at the actual [[Plaza Hotel]] in [[New York City]], so it had the hotel recreated on sound stages. To recoup construction costs, [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] built a sitcom called ''[[The Nutt House]]'' around it. [[Jim Abrahams]] said he staged one of the boardroom scenes based on an experience he had when a large agency used many employees to get him to sign with them. ==Reception== Critical reaction to the film as a whole was generally lukewarm. The review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 40% of critics gave the film a positive rating, based on 15 reviews, with an average score of 4.9/10.{{cite web |title=Big Business (1988) |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1002310-big_business/ |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate= October 24, 2013}} [[Sheila Benson]] from ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' called ''Big Business'' a "bright whirligig of a movie" and added: "As you watch its buoyant hilarity, the intricacies flow smoothly as honey off a spoon [...] Like a sensational party the night before, "Big Business" may not bear the closest scrutiny in the cold light of day, but it gives an irresistible glow at the time. And when it gets on a roll, it's a movie with more wit to its lines and a more pungent array of them than much of the mishmash that has passed as Bette Midler's ''Greatest Movie Hits''."{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-06-10/entertainment/ca-4864_1_big-business|first=Sheila |last=Benson|title=Midler, Tomlin Do a Twin Turn in 'Big Business'|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 10, 1988|accessdate= October 24, 2013}} ''[[Philadelphia Daily News]]'' writer [[Ben Yagoda]] felt that the film was "big fun. Lily Tomlin and Bette Midler are a double dose of hilarity. Call out the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] — ''Big Business'' is a laugh riot".{{cite web |url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-06-10/news/26268953_1_big-business-dori-pierson-ruthless-people|first=Ben |last= Yagoda|title=In 'Business' For Big Laughs|work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]|date=June 10, 1988|accessdate= October 24, 2013}} In his review for ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Vincent Canby]] remarked that ''Big Business'', "though it never quite delivers the boffo payoff, is a most cheerful, very breezy summer farce, played to the hilt by two splendidly comic performers [...] Sometimes [the film's writers] do have trouble in characterizing the two sets of twins, allowing them to blend in such a way that the comic edge finally becomes blurred. Yet the film moves at such a clip, and with such uncommon zest, that it's good fun even when the invention wears thin."{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-06-10/entertainment/ca-4864_1_big-business|first=Vincent |last=Canby |title=A Tomlin-Midler Comedy of Errors|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 10, 1988|accessdate= October 24, 2013}} [[Roger Ebert]], writing for the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', gave the film two out of four stars. He declared the film "an endless and dreary series of scenes in which the various twins just barely miss running into each other in the Plaza Hotel," and found that it felt "unfinished" and missed a payoff.{{cite web |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20120502/REVIEWS/120509993|first=Roger |last=Ebert|title=The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel|publisher=RogertEbert.com|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date= 2 May 2012|accessdate= 30 October 2012}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called the film "a shrill, unattractive comedy." The staff felt that Midler's "loud brashness generally dominated [Tomlin's] sly skittishness".{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/1987/film/reviews/big-business-1200427659/|first=|last=Variety Staff|title=Review: ‘Big Business’|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date= December 31, 1987|accessdate= October 24, 2013}} ===Box office=== In the United States, ''Big Business'' debuted within the top three on the [[box office]] chart and became a modest success, eventually grossing $40,150,487 during its domestic run.{{cite news|title= Wanda' Heads Upstream|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1989-03-16/entertainment/ca-1688_1_big-business|accessdate=2012-06-10}}{{cite web|title=''Big Business''|work=The Numbers|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1988/0BBUS.php|accessdate=2009-01-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090211074525/http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1988/0BBUS.php| archivedate= 11 February 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|title= WEEKEND BOX OFFICE : 'Crocodile' Swamps 'Rambo'; Hanks' 'Big' Hit|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1988-06-14/entertainment/ca-4175_1_big-business|accessdate=2012-06-10}} ==Home Media== The film was released to VHS and laserdisc in 1989 by [[Touchstone Home Video]], with a DVD release in 2002. In 2011, ''Big Business'' was among a selection of titles from [[Touchstone Pictures|Touchstone]] and [[Hollywood Pictures]] to be licensed to [[Mill Creek Entertainment]], and a DVD and Blu-ray disc were released of the film. The DVD is available on its own, as a double-feature with ''[[Straight Talk]]'', and as a triple-feature with ''Straight Talk'' and ''[[V.I. Warshawski (film)|V.I. Warshawski]]''. In December 2017, ''Big Business'' and ''[[Scenes from a Mall]]'' will release on Blu-ray by [[Kino International (company)|Kino Lorber]] under Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment license.[https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B076DQVTG5/panandscathed-20 Big Business / Scenes from a Mall Bette Midler Double Feature] ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Saving Grace | type = Soundtrack | artist = Various Artists | cover = | alt = | released = 1988 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[film music]] | length = | label = | producer = [[Marc Shaiman]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Album ratings|rev1= [[Allmusic]]|rev1Score= {{Rating|3|5}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20090603090016/http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg link] }} ===''Music from the Motion Picture'' album=== '''Track listing''' # [[Steve Winwood]] — "[[Higher Love]]" (Steve Winwood, [[Will Jennings]]) # “Little Ole Lady” (Richard Wilbur, [[Marc Shaiman]]) # [[Benny Goodman]] — "[[Sing, Sing, Sing]]" ([[Louis Prima]]) # “[[Pennies from Heaven (song)|Pennies from Heaven]]" ([[Johnny Burke (lyricist)|Johnny Burke]], [[Arthur Johnston (composer)|Arthur Johnston]]) # [[George Benson]] — “[[On Broadway (song)|On Broadway]]" ([[Jerry Leiber]], [[Mike Stoller]], [[Barry Mann]], [[Cynthia Weil]]) # The Trinidad Serenaders Steel Band — "[[Music Box Dancer]]" ([[Frank Mills]]) # “Reilly Theme” (E. Shostakovich) # "[[I'm in the Mood for Love]]" ([[Jimmy McHugh]], [[Dorothy Fields]]) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0094739}} {{Zucker, Abrahams and Zucker}} {{The Comedy of Errors}} {{The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Big Business (1988 Film)}} [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:1980s buddy films]] [[Category:1980s business films]] [[Category:1980s comedy films]] [[Category:American business films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:American female buddy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Lee Holdridge]] [[Category:Films about twin sisters]] [[Category:Films based on The Comedy of Errors]] [[Category:Films directed by Jim Abrahams]] [[Category:Films set in hotels]] [[Category:Films set in 1948]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Films set in West Virginia]] [[Category:Touchstone Pictures films]] [[Category:Mill Creek Entertainment]]

[[File:Bjørn Ole Gleditsch.JPG|thumb|Bjørn Ole Gleditsch 2010]] '''Bjørn Ole Gleditsch''' (born 13 January 1963) is a Norwegian businessperson and politician for the [[Conservative Party of Norway|Conservative Party]].
Since 2003 he is the mayor of [[Sandefjord]]. Before this he served several terms in the [[municipal council (Norway)|municipal council]].<ref name="H">[http://www.hoyre.no/personer/Bjorn%20Ole%20Gleditsch Conservative Party biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904042510/http://www.hoyre.no/personer/Bjorn%20Ole%20Gleditsch |date=September 4, 2010 }}</ref>
Gleditsch is the richest mayor of any municipality of Norway. The grandson of [[Odd Gleditsch, Sr.|Odd Gleditsch]], he is an heir of the paint company [[Jotun (company)|Jotun]]. Through shareholding, he has a fortune of NOK 480 million,<ref>{{cite news |first=Stig |last=Flesland |title=Norges rikeste ordfører |url=http://www.na24.no/article2245090.ece |work=NS24.no |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-27 }}</ref> approximately 86.9 million U.S. dollars.
He is also a member of the board of [[Sandefjord Airport, Torp]].<ref name="H"/>

{{Infobox Prime Minister |name = David Amaglobeli
დავით ამაღლობელი |image = Davit amaglobeli.jpg |imagesize = 250px |office = Former Governor of the National Bank of Georgia |term_start = October 2007 |term_end = February 2009 |president = |predecessor = |successor = |office2 = |term_start2 = |term_end2 = |predecessor2 = |successor2 = |office3 = |term_start3 = |term_end3 = |predecessor3 = |successor3 = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|8|8|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]) |death_date = |death_place = |website = }} '''David Amaglobeli''' ([[Georgian language|georg]]. დავით ამაღლობელი) is a [[Georgians|Georgian]] economist who was acting president of the [[National Bank of Georgia]] (NBG) between October 2007 and February 2009. == Biography == Amaglobeli was born on August 8, 1976 in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. In 1998 he graduated with a diploma in economics from [[Tbilisi State University]] and in 2001 he received the degree of Master of Science in Economics from [[Oregon State University]]. In 1998-1999 David Amaglobeli worked as an economist at the committee of economic policy and reforms at the [[Parliament of Georgia]] and in 1999-2001, in parallel to his graduate studies, he worked as a research/teaching assistant. In 2001-02 David Amaglobeli worked as the department head at the ministry of tax revenues of Georgia and in 2002-03 as a consultant to the government of Georgia on fiscal and monetary policy issues for the state commission responsible for the development of poverty reduction and growth program. From January 2004 David Amaglobeli worked as a fiscal economist at the [[International Monetary Fund]] local office in Tbilisi and the same year he was appointed as a deputy minister of finance. From March 2005 till October 2009 David Amaglobeli served as a deputy governor and from October 2007 till February 2009 as acting governor of the NBG. In his capacity of the governor of the NBG, David Amaglobeli initiated various legislative and institutional reforms. In particular, inflation targeting was adopted as the monetary policy regime, monetary policy committee and main policy interest rate were introduced, a transparent foreign currency auction system was adopted as the main instrument for market interventions. As a result of institutional reforms the size of staff was significantly reduced, and payment systems (cash and cash free) and reserve management reform projects were initiated. During David Amaglobeli’s tenure at the NBG, the country experienced severe exogenous shocks. Despite the severe consequences from war with Russia in August 2008 and from the deepening of the global financial crisis in September 2008, the country maintained macroeconomic and banking sector stability. == External links == * [http://www.nbg.gov.ge/index.php?m=436 Official biography of the Governor of the National Bank of Georgia] {{DEFAULTSORT:Amaglobeli, David}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Tbilisi]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Georgian economists]]

{{Infobox person | name = Dhimitër Emanoil (Mborja) | image = Dhimiter_Emanoil_Mborja.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Dhimitër Emanoil | birth_date = 1884 | birth_place = [[Mborje]], [[Manastir Vilayet]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | death_date = 1945 | death_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]] | nationality = [[Albanians|Albanian]] | citizenship = [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]], [[Romania]]n | other_names = Dhimitër Emanoili
Dhimitër Mborja
Dimitri Emanuel
Dimitri Mola | occupation = Entrepreneur, merchant | known_for = {{nowrap|[[Albanian Declaration of Independence]]
Albanian Colony of Bucharest
[[Albanian Congress of Trieste]]}} }} '''Dhimitër Mborja Emanoili''' (1884–1945) was an [[Albanians|Albanian]] politician, businessman and benefactor. He was one of the signatories of the [[Albanian Declaration of Independence]] as a representative of the Albanian community of Romania."History of Albanian People" Albanian Academy of Science.{{ISBN|99927-1-623-1}}{{citation| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vpIFsca3lKYC&pg=PA320&dq=dhimiter+zografi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0w_HUrepBuvIsASDmILIDw&ved=0CFAQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=ilo.%20spiro&f=false| author=Michael Schmidt-Neke | page=320|title=Entstehung und Ausbau der Königsdiktatur in Albanien (1912-1939): Regierungsbildungen, Herrschaftsweise und Machteliten in einem jungen Balkanstaat| date=16 November 1987| isbn=978-3486543216 | publisher=Oldenbourg Wissenschaftsverlag }} == Life == Dhimitër Mborja was born in [[Mborje]], modern [[Korçë District]] (then part of the [[Manastir Vilayet]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]]) in 1884. At the age of sixteen, with his father, Viskë and his brothers emigrated to Bucharest. Their house in Mborje was donated in order to house the Albanian-language school of the village.{{Cite news|url=http://www.gazeta-shqip.com/ndryshe/3fc09d99bd85ed29c4329cce9c4855d3.html|title=Delegatët e Kolonisë së Bukureshtit në Kuvendin e Vlorës|last=Kotherja|first=Niko|date=July 23, 2009|work=Gazeta Shqip|accessdate=3 October 2012}} In 1908 he joined the ''Dituria'' association of Korçë. Mborja emigrated to Bucharest where his name appears as the owner of a "Carpati" club and the leader of the Albanian community there. On November 5, 1912, he was elected by the Albanian community of Bucharest to become a representative of the Albanians of Romania in the assembly of Vlorë, where he signed the [[Albanian Declaration of Independence]] as "D. Emanuel".[http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts20_1/AH1912_1.html 1912 - The Declaration of Albanian Independence (by Robert Elsie)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507000000/http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts20_1/AH1912_1.html |date=May 7, 2011 }}
His brother, Pandeli was an adjutant of [[Ismail Qemali]] during that period, while his younger brother, Nuç served under [[Themistokli Gërmenji]]. Mborja also donated 1,000 gold napoleons to the ministry of finances of the provisional government.
Mborja as a delegate of the Bucharest colony at the [[Albanian Congress of Trieste]] in 1913.
In 1915 he was elected a councillor of the ''Albanian Orthodox Community of Bucharest'' organization, which also operated an Albanian-language school in the city. In 1919-21 he donated his mansion in Korçë to house the [[Albanian National Lyceum]]. A supporter of [[Fan Noli]], he participated in the 1924 June Revolution that overthrew [[Ahmet Zogu]]'s regime. After Zogu's return, he was self-exiled. Mborja died in 1945 in Bucharest.{{cite news|url=http://www.albaniapress.com/lajme/9742/diaspora-e-atdhetareve-te-harruar-dhimiter-emanoil-1884-1945.html|title=Diaspora e atdhetarëve të harruar: Dhimitër Emanoil (1884-1945)|last=Ymeri|first=Baki|date=September 7, 2009|publisher=Albania Press|accessdate=5 October 2012}} On November 27, 1992 he was posthumously awarded the "Medal for Patriotic Activity" ({{lang-sq|Medalje Për Veprimtari Patriotike}}), which was received by his descendants in Korçë. == See also == Other delegates of the Albanian community of Romania: *[[Dhimitër Zografi]] *[[Dhimitër Ilo]] *[[Dhimitër Beratti]] *[[Spiridon Ilo]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mborja, Dhimiter}} [[Category:1884 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:People from Korçë]] [[Category:People from Manastir Vilayet]] [[Category:Albanians of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox Christians from Albania]] [[Category:Albanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Signatories of the Albanian Declaration of Independence]] [[Category:Albanian expatriates in Romania]] [[Category:All-Albanian Congress delegates]]

revision.text:
A '''digital strategy manager''' is an executive position. This position is based on a unique set of technological knowledge which directs all departments for digital industry growth.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1108/SD-04-2013-0011|author=David Dumeresque|year=2013|title=The corporate digital footprint: exactly who owns and controls it? The emergence of the digital director|journal=Strategic Direction|volume=29|issue=7|pp=34–36|quote=The concept of the digital director is now emerging. The head of digital strategy will have ultimate control of the corporate digital agenda and be accountable for the organization's digital identity, both on a corporate and an individual level.}}</ref> A digital strategy manager collaborates with all [[marketing]], [[business development]], and organizational management teams and uses leadership skills to build [[strategic partnership]]s.<ref>{{cite web|author= Tim Williams |url=http://www.ignitiongroup.com/guide/role-description-digital-strategy-director/ |title=Role description: Digital Strategy Director - Ignition Consulting Group |publisher=Ignitiongroup.com |date=2010-06-22 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
This position focuses specifically on a [[corporation]]’s digital brand by leading, building and maintaining their presence in the digital world. Accountable for driving the prioritization of the technology infrastructure for [[digital advertising]] continuity across all multi-media platforms. Manages all related IT departments and functions as a conduit between digital presence and all advertising and/or marketing activities. Consults with all internal directors strategizing their specific marketing needs incorporating the [[digital technology]] structure.<ref>{{cite journal|title=What is Your Digital Business Strategy?|author1=Mithas, Sunil |author2=Lucas Jr, Henry C. |journal=IT Professional Magazine|volume=12|issue=6|date=Nov–Dec 2010|pages=4–6|url=http://search.proquest.com/technologycollection/docview/815992403}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Chief digital officer]] * [[Chief innovation officer]] * [[Chief data officer]] * [[Chief marketing officer]]
